title: Insecure Transportation Security Protocol Supported (TLS 1.0)

profile.name: Gratipay
profile.about: Gratitude? Gratipay! The easiest way for your company to pay for open source.

vulnerability_information:
Description: Its observed that that insecure transportation security protocol (TLS 1.0) is supported by your web server. TLS 1.0 has several flaws. An attacker can cause connection failures and they can trigger the use of TLS 1.0 to exploit vulnerabilities like BEAST.
Websites using TLS 1.0 will be considered non-compliant by PCI after 30 June 2018.

Impact: Attackers can perform man-in-the-middle attacks and observe the encryption traffic between your website and its visitors.

Recommended Fix: Configure your web server to disallow using weak ciphers. You need to restart the web server to enable changes.

By fingerprinting server, found that its Nginx Web server. So below is solution for Nginx
For Nginx, locate any use of the directive ssl_protocols in the nginx.conf file and remove TLSv1.
ssl_protocols TLSv1.1 TLSv1.2;

activities.message:
Hi @yodha,

Thanks for this report! [As stated](https://github.com/gratipay/inside.gratipay.com/commit/a350afda748237d57a98e7775682c9ea6fd3f24a) (and in some public reports), our goal is to get a A on ssllabs, since they already test these kind of attacks (and being vulnerable means they give a very bad mark). However, they can make mistakes in their recommendations and we'll happy to discuss of your report. Are you talking of https://gratipay.com?

Thanks for making Gratipay a safer place!

Yes this is regarding gratipay.com and its not observed / identified from ssllabs as its third party service. I used free opensource tools available in Kali Linux and confirmed that TLS 1.0 is supported by server and its not secure. So its recommended to start working on fix for this issue. Please let me know if require any more information from my side.

Hi again @yodha,

Thanks for this report. Since it's a not a risk (it's only a CSS on a domain serving unrelated static content—implementing SRI is just one small improvement), I'm closing this one as duplicate of your first report. 

Thanks for making Gratipay a safer place!
@nashe_ Looks like mistake as you saying its duplicate of #161765 which is SRI implementation issue and nothing with TLS. Could you please recheck?

Yep, sorry, it was reopened just before your last message. 

First thing, https://gratipay.com is hosted on Heroku and we are dependent of their choices regarding SSL/TLS. [Their Director Of Security (jacobian) posted a nice response on Gratipay's repository about BEAST mitigation on Heroku](https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/issues/1460).

Regarding SSLLabs, you are allowed to run this tool against our servers, since the noise generate is nearly null. The sentence about automated scans in our policy is more to avoid getting copied and pasted Acunetix reports (same with w3af, etc…). 

[As SSLLabs explain](https://blog.qualys.com/ssllabs/2013/09/10/is-beast-still-a-threat), the fix for BEAST is client-side and no good server-side fix exists (except enabling only RC4), thus they don't consider it's a real risk anymore. It's still enabled when using Mozilla's "Intermediate profile" too.

I'm closing this report as "Informative" since no direct security risk is present. Thanks for your report @yodha!
